pre_demo_screens: Welcome to the study, and thank you for agreeing to take part.
In this study you will be asked to program a synthesiser to create sounds in response to some descriptive words.
The following pages contain instructions on how to complete the experiment. Please read them carefully.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
In order to complete the study, you must be using the latest version of the Google Chrome browser on a laptop or desktop computer.
You should also use headphones or reference monitor speakers.
Please do not attempt to complete the study using laptop speakers.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
Before continuing, we must adjust the volume of your listening apparatus.
Please ensure that no other sound is playing on your computer and follow these steps carefully.
First, turn down your computer volume until it makes no sound.
It is important to reduce the volume rather than simply pressing mute.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
Click play on the audio player below. Once started, the player will loop automatically.
Now, gradually increase your computer's volume until the white noise is at a comfortable listening level.
It is important that you do not change your computer's volume for the rest of the experiment.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
When the experiment starts, you will be presented with a simple FM synthesiser, which will already be programmed to produce a sound.
Above the synthesiser, you will see an instruction to alter the sound in some way. For example, you might be asked to make a sound brighter, or less rough.
Your task is to alter the parameters of the synthesiser in order to match the description given. You may take as much time as you wish to achieve this.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
The synthesiser is a three operator FM synthesiser.
The operators are organised according to the following algorithm:
This means that operator one is the carrier, and operators two and three both directly modulate its frequency.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
On the next screen, you will be able to practice making a sound with the synthesiser.
Please take as much time as you need to familiarise yourself with the controls.
You can play notes using the piano keyboard at the bottom of the screen.

You can also use your computer keyboard. The keys in the row from from A-L correspond to the white notes, and the keys W, E, T, Y, U and O correspond to the black notes. You can use the Z and X keys to change octave.
Once you are finished, you can click the submit button to move on.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
post_demo_screens: After you have submitted your sound, you will be asked some questions about the sound you have created.
There is no right or wrong response to these questions. Please simply answer to the best of your ability.
When you are ready to continue, please press any key to move to the next screen
You will be asked to create 10 sounds. Once you are done, you will be asked a few short questions.
The experiment will begin on the next screen. When you are ready, press any key to start.
